query: What are the differences between how men and women bow when performing New Year's greetings (Sebae)?
knowledge: The methods for performing Sebae (New Year's bow) differ clearly between men and women. Men perform a full prostration called Keunjeol (also known as Pyeongjeol or Gyesubae), placing their left hand on top when clasping hands together. Specifically, from the Gongsu position (hands clasped), they kneel down, place their hands on the ground, and bow until their forehead touches their hands. Women, on the other hand, perform a half-bow called Banjeol (also known as Sukbae or Pyeongbae), placing their right hand on top when clasping hands. They kneel and place their hands on the ground but only bend their upper body without lowering their forehead. This distinction originates from Confucian etiquette that differentiated between men's and women's physical characteristics and social roles, applying the principle of 'Namjwayeou' (남좌여우) - left for men, right for women. The hand position, whether the forehead touches the ground, and the depth of the bow all differ. While some modern women perform full prostrations, traditional etiquette maintains clear distinctions.

query: What does Hongdongbaekseo mean when setting up an ancestral memorial table?
knowledge: Hongdongbaekseo (紅東白西) is one of the fundamental principles for arranging ritual offerings, meaning 'red fruits on the east, white fruits on the west.' Specifically, red-colored fruits such as jujubes, persimmons, and apples are placed on the east side (left from the officiant's perspective), while white or light-colored fruits such as chestnuts, pears, and dried persimmons are placed on the west side (right from the officiant's perspective). This principle originates from the Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy, where the east symbolizes Yang and the west symbolizes Yin, with red representing Yang energy and white representing Yin energy. Along with Joyulisi (棗栗梨柿 - the order of jujube, chestnut, pear, and persimmon), this is the most basic principle for arranging ancestral tables. While regional variations exist and modern practice may not strictly follow these rules, Hongdongbaekseo remains a universal principle in most Confucian rituals. Traditionally, fruits are placed in the first row, with the head of fish positioned toward the east. Although the specifics may vary by region and family lineage, Hongdongbaekseo is the most commonly observed principle.

query: What is the difference between Charye and Jesa?
knowledge: Charye (茶禮) and Jesa (祭祀) are both rituals honoring ancestors, but they differ in purpose and procedure. Charye is a simplified ceremony held on holidays (Lunar New Year, Chuseok, etc.), typically performed during daytime (morning hours), and may include tea or sikhye instead of alcohol. The food offerings center on holiday dishes (tteokguk for New Year, songpyeon for Chuseok) and are arranged simply, with relatively straightforward procedures. In contrast, Gijesa (忌祭祀) is a formal memorial service held on the anniversary of an ancestor's death (Giil), beginning just after midnight or in the early morning hours (around 12-2 AM), and includes complex procedures such as Heonjak (獻酌), the ritual of offering alcohol. The memorial table is arranged in five rows following strict presentation rules. Sijae (時祭) is a memorial service performed at the gravesite, typically during Hansik or in October. In summary, Charye is characterized by 'holiday + simplified + daytime,' while Jesa is 'death anniversary + formal + midnight.' Although these distinctions have become blurred in modern times, traditional etiquette clearly differentiates between them.

query: How many times do the bride and groom bow during the Gyobaerye ceremony in a traditional wedding?
knowledge: During the Gyobaerye (交拜禮) ceremony in traditional weddings, the bride and groom each bow twice to each other. This is called 'Ibaejirye (再拜之禮)' or 'Ibae (再拜),' meaning 'two bows.' The specific procedure is as follows: First, the groom performs two full prostrations to the bride, then the bride performs two half-bows (women's bows) to the groom. This symbolizes mutual respect and the establishment of an equal relationship between husband and wife. Gyobaerye is performed at the Chorye-cheong (醮禮廳, the wedding venue) and is a core ceremony in traditional weddings, following the sequence of Jeonanrye (奠雁禮, presenting the wooden goose), Gyobaerye, and Hapgeunrye (合卺禮, sharing ceremonial wine). The number two symbolizes the harmony of Yin and Yang and represents the union of two individuals becoming one. While modern weddings often simplify or omit this ceremony, it is an essential procedure in traditional weddings.

query: Which hand should you use when offering food or objects to elders?
knowledge: When offering food or objects to elders, you must always present them with both hands held respectfully. This is called 'Gongsubeop (拱手法)' and is a core principle of Korean traditional etiquette. Specifically, you should place your right hand underneath and your left hand on top (in normal circumstances), hold the object at chest height, and offer it respectfully with both hands. Men clasp their hands with the left on top and right below (normally), while women place the right hand on top and left below. This follows the 'Namjwayeou (男左女右)' principle - left for men, right for women. Using only the right hand violates etiquette, and offering something with one hand is considered disrespectful. Especially when presenting alcohol cups, meal tables, or gifts, you must use both hands. When offering items, bowing slightly at the waist and lowering your gaze demonstrates even greater respect. This etiquette is a fundamental courtesy in Confucian culture, expressing reverence and respect for elders.

query: What time should songpyeon be prepared for Chuseok Charye?
knowledge: Chuseok Charye is held in the morning of the holiday, generally between 7 and 9 AM after sunrise. Therefore, the table with songpyeon must be prepared before that time. Traditionally, food preparation began at dawn (around 5-6 AM) to have everything ready for the ceremony at sunrise. This contrasts with Gijesa, which is held at midnight (12 AM), as Charye is characteristically performed during bright daylight hours. Songpyeon is an essential food for Chuseok Charye, placed between the first row (fruits) and second row (vegetables, dried fish) or in the third row, served either in a steamer or on a plate. The timing may vary slightly by household tradition and region, but the common element is 'morning hours after sunrise.' While modern families often perform the ceremony whenever family members can gather during the morning, traditionally, the time shortly after sunrise was considered most appropriate.

query: What is the order for putting on men's hanbok, including baji and jeogori?
knowledge: The order for putting on men's hanbok is as follows. First, put on undergarments: sokjeoksam (undershirt) and goi (underpants). Next, put on the outer trousers called baji, tying them securely with a waistband. The baji has wide legs gathered at the ankles with daenim (leg bands). Then put on the jeogori (jacket) and fasten it with the goreum (ties), ensuring the right panel is inside and the left panel is outside (Uim, 右衽). For formal attire, wear a vest or magoja over the jeogori, then add a durumagi (overcoat). Finally, put on a gat (traditional hat) or jeonrip, along with beoseon (socks) and shoes. In summary: 'undergarments (sokjeoksam + goi) → baji → jeogori → vest/magoja → durumagi → hat → socks/shoes.' This sequence follows the principle of dressing from inside to outside, from bottom to top, considering both the function and ceremonial significance of each garment. Modern casual hanbok may simplify some of these steps.

query: What does Eodongyukseomean on an ancestral memorial table and where is it placed?
knowledge: Eodongyukseo (魚東肉西) is a core principle for arranging memorial tables, meaning 'fish on the east, meat on the west.' Specifically, fish dishes are placed on the east side (left from the officiant's perspective), and meat dishes are placed on the west side (right from the officiant's perspective). This originates from Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy, where the east corresponds to Wood and the west to Metal. Fish, associated with water, is placed on the east, while terrestrial animal meat is placed on the west for harmony. A related principle is 'Saengdongsukseo (生東熟西),' meaning raw foods (fresh vegetables, kimchi, etc.) go on the east and cooked foods (namul, etc.) go on the west. Along with Hongdongbaekseo (red fruits east, white fruits west) and Joyulisi (jujube-chestnut-pear-persimmon order), this forms the four major principles for setting memorial tables. Traditionally, fish and meat are placed in the third row, with the fish's head facing east. While specific rules may vary by region and family lineage, Eodongyukseo is the most universal principle.

query: What types of mourning garments do chief mourners wear in traditional funeral rites?
knowledge: In traditional funeral rites, mourning garments are categorized into five types according to the Obok system (五服制度). First, Chamchoe (斬衰) is the heaviest mourning garment, worn by sons for their father or grandfather, made of rough raw hemp and worn for three years. Second, Jachoe (齊衰) is the next heaviest mourning garment, worn by sons for their mother and wives for their husbands, made of finely processed hemp and worn for one or three years. Third, Daegong (大功) is worn for siblings, nephews/nieces, etc., made of coarse hemp cloth and worn for nine months. Fourth, Sogong (小功) is worn for relatives within five degrees of kinship, made of fine hemp cloth and worn for five months. Fifth, Sima (緦麻) is the lightest mourning garment, worn for distant relatives or teacher-student relationships, made of fine hemp cloth and worn for three months. In modern times, mourning garments have been simplified to white or black clothing, but traditional Confucian etiquette strictly differentiated the material, color, and wearing period of mourning garments according to blood relations and kinship.

query: How many times is the hat changed during the Gwallye coming-of-age ceremony?
knowledge: In the traditional coming-of-age ceremony Gwallye (冠禮), the hat is changed three times. This is called 'Samgarye (三加禮),' consisting of Choga (初加), Jaega (再加), and Samga (三加). In Choga, the hair is raised into a topknot and a black pogeon (布巾, headband) is worn, symbolizing departure from childhood. In Jaega, the pogeon is removed and a gat (立纓, hat with raised strings) is worn, signifying taking on social responsibilities as an adult. In Samga, the ipyeong is removed and a samo (紗帽) or bokdu (幞頭) is worn, symbolizing qualification to enter public service. At each stage, a congratulatory text is read and bows are performed. The three stages collectively grant full recognition as an adult. The number three symbolizes completion in Confucianism, representing the harmony of heaven, earth, and humanity (天地人). The women's coming-of-age ceremony Gyerye (笄禮) similarly involves three stages of inserting hairpins. While modern coming-of-age ceremonies are simplified, Samgarye is the core ritual in traditional Gwallye.

query: What does Joyulisi mean in the arrangement of memorial tables?
knowledge: Joyulisi (棗栗梨柿) indicates the order for arranging fruits in the first row of a memorial table, from left to right: jujube (棗), chestnut (栗), pear (梨), and dried persimmon (柿). This reflects the symbolic meaning of each fruit and the principles of Yin-Yang and Five Elements. Jujubes have a single pit, symbolizing devotion and singular loyalty. Chestnuts split into three pieces, representing the Three Bonds (三綱: ruler-subject, father-son, husband-wife). Pears are white inside and refreshing, symbolizing purity. Dried persimmons, from which the astringency has been removed, represent patience and maturation. Additionally, jujubes and chestnuts are closer to the east (Yang) while pears and persimmons are closer to the west (Yin), creating Yin-Yang harmony. While the order may vary by region (e.g., jujube-chestnut-persimmon-pear), the principle of placing jujubes and chestnuts on the east remains consistent. Along with Hongdongbaekseo and Eodongyukseo, this is one of the three fundamental principles for memorial table arrangement, still valued in households observing traditional practices.

query: What procedures constitute the Yungnye (Six Rites) of a traditional wedding?
knowledge: Yungnye (六禮) are the six procedures of a traditional wedding, representing the most formal marriage process in Confucian etiquette. First, Napchae (納采) is when the groom's family conveys their intention to marry and receives the bride's Sajudanja (birth date and time information). Second, Munmyeong (問名) is when they ask for the bride's name and birth date to confirm compatibility. Third, Napgil (納吉) is when, after checking astrological compatibility, they inform the bride's family that the marriage is suitable. Fourth, Napjing (納徵) is when the marriage is confirmed and the groom's family sends gifts to the bride's family - this corresponds to the modern Hamjinabie (함진아비, gift bearer). Fifth, Cheonggi (請期) is when the wedding date is set and communicated to the bride's family. Sixth, Chinyeong (親迎) is when the groom personally goes to the bride's home to receive her and perform the wedding ceremony, including Jeonanrye, Gyobaerye, and Hapgeunrye. Modern weddings have simplified this to sending the ham (gift box) and venue ceremonies, but traditional wedding reenactments follow the Yungnye sequence.

query: How are rice and soup positioned in traditional table setting?
knowledge: In traditional table setting, rice and soup placement follows the 'Jwabanugyaeng (左飯右羹)' principle, meaning 'rice on the left, soup on the right.' This arrangement, from the diner's perspective, allows them to hold the rice bowl with their left hand and use a spoon with their right hand to eat soup comfortably. Specifically, rice is placed on the left, soup on the right, and stew next to or behind the soup. Spoons and chopsticks are placed at the right edge of the table or between the rice and soup, with the spoon above and chopsticks below, arranged parallel. Side dishes are arranged behind the rice and soup, with kimchi and condiments typically in the back right, and namul (seasoned vegetables) and braised dishes in the back left. This arrangement reflects practical wisdom considering dining flow as well as Yin-Yang harmony. While this principle has weakened in modern times, it is still observed in traditional Korean table settings and memorial food service. When setting a guest's table, Jwabanugyaeng serves as the foundation and is considered a basic courtesy in Korean food culture.

query: How many times is the ritual cup offering (Heonjak) performed during ancestral rites?
knowledge: In traditional ancestral rites, Heonjak (獻酌) is performed three times. These are called Choheon (初獻), Aheon (亞獻), and Jongheon (終獻), meaning first, second, and third offerings respectively. Choheon is usually performed by the eldest grandson or chief officiant, who lights incense, offers the first cup, and bows. Aheon is performed by the next in rank (second son or the officiant's wife), offering the second cup. Jongheon is performed by the third in rank, and after offering the final cup, the spoon is placed in the rice and chopsticks are set. Between each offering, procedures such as Dokchuk (讀祝, reading the prayer) or Sapsijeongja (揷匙正箸, placing spoon and chopsticks) are included. The number three symbolizes the completeness of heaven, earth, and humanity (天地人), and offering cups three times demonstrates utmost sincerity. While modern practice may involve only one offering or omit this procedure, formal Confucian rites maintain the Samheonrye (three offerings) as principle.

query: What is the meaning of jujubes and chestnuts prepared for Pyebaek?
knowledge: In Pyebaek (幣帛), jujubes and chestnuts are the most important items symbolizing fertility and prosperity. Jujubes have the character '棗' pronounced similarly to '早' (early), conveying the wish to 'have children early.' With one seed per fruit, they represent sincere childbirth. Additionally, their red color symbolizes Yang and expresses the wish for sons. Chestnuts contain three nuts per burr, meaning to have many children and wishing for descendants who uphold the Three Bonds and Five Relationships. Their white color symbolizes Yin, creating Yin-Yang harmony with the red jujubes. During Pyebaek, when the parents-in-law toss jujubes and chestnuts into the bride's skirt, the bride catches them - folklore says the more she catches, the more children she will have. The number of jujubes and chestnuts caught was used to predict the number of sons and daughters. This custom combines the emphasis on continuing the family line in Confucian society with Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy.

query: What is the meaning of washing hair with iris water on Dano?
knowledge: Washing hair with iris water on Dano (端午, 5th day of the 5th lunar month) is a major seasonal custom for women. Iris (菖蒲) is a medicinal plant with fragrant roots and leaves that have antibacterial and cleansing effects. Washing hair with water boiled from iris roots makes hair shiny and soft, prevents scalp diseases, and repels insects, making it useful for summer hygiene. The iris was also considered a 'divine herb' with mystical power to ward off evil and bring good fortune. Dano is when Yang energy is strongest, and the belief was that washing hair with iris water on this day would ensure health and abundant hair throughout the year. While men wore iris at their waist or engaged in wrestling (ssireum), women washed their hair with iris water and enjoyed swinging. Although this custom has largely disappeared in modern times, the experience of washing hair with iris water is still offered at traditional festivals such as the Gangneung Dano Festival.

query: Why is red bean porridge eaten on Dongji (winter solstice) and what is its meaning?
knowledge: The custom of eating red bean porridge on Dongji (冬至) originates from the belief that red beans ward off evil spirits and bad fortune. Dongji is the day with the longest night of the year, when Yin energy peaks and ghosts and evil spirits were believed to be most active. Red, the color of Yang, was thought to frighten evil spirits, so the red color of beans was believed to repel demons and prevent misfortune. Therefore, Dongji red bean porridge was sprinkled around the house (gates, jangdokdae/jar stands, storage areas) to prevent disasters throughout the year. Additionally, the number of saealsim (glutinous rice balls) added to the porridge matched one's age, representing gaining another year. There's even a saying that 'one becomes a year older only after passing Dongji.' Dongji was also called 'small New Year,' and people believed the true new year began after eating red bean porridge. The custom of eating red bean porridge on Dongji continues today, established as a seasonal food for wishing health and family well-being.

query: What etiquette should be observed when smoking or drinking alcohol in front of elders?
knowledge: In traditional etiquette, smoking or drinking alcohol in front of elders should be strictly avoided. For tobacco, the principle is to absolutely not smoke in front of parents, teachers, or other respected elders. If smoking is unavoidable, one must ask permission first, then turn away so the smoke does not reach the elder. When drinking alcohol, one should drink only after the elder has taken their cup first, and use both hands when receiving and drinking. When drinking, turn one's head to the side so the face does not face the elder - this is called 'turning to drink.' Also, becoming intoxicated before the elder or speaking loudly is considered impolite. When exchanging cups, the respectful posture is to hold the cup with the right hand while supporting the right forearm or chest with the left hand. This etiquette is based on the Confucian concept of Jangyuyuseo (長幼有序, proper order between elders and juniors), expressing respect and reverence for elders as everyday courtesy.

query: What is the origin of the Korean culture of removing shoes at the door when guests arrive?
knowledge: In Korea, the culture of removing shoes before entering indoors originated from the ondol heating system and floor-based living. Traditional Korean homes used ondol floor heating, making the floor the living space. All activities - eating, studying, sleeping - took place on the floor, so keeping it clean was crucial. Entering with outdoor shoes would dirty the floor, making life inconvenient and unhygienic. Additionally, Confucian etiquette considered 'the inside of the house as sacred space,' so shoes were removed to avoid bringing outside dust and impurity indoors. The architectural structure of having a shoe-removing area (toeumaru) between the wooden-floor hall and rooms supports this culture. Modern apartments continue this structure with an entryway for removing shoes, reflecting Koreans' cleanliness consciousness and the distinction between indoor and outdoor spaces. When receiving guests, having them remove shoes is considered proper etiquette, and providing indoor slippers is common.

query: What is the meaning of the groom bringing a wooden goose to the bride's house in traditional weddings?
knowledge: In the Jeonanrye (奠雁禮) of traditional weddings, the groom bringing a wooden goose to the bride's house symbolizes marital fidelity and virtue. Geese (雁) are legendary for mating for life and never taking another mate after their partner dies, thus symbolizing faithfulness and chastity between spouses. Additionally, geese migrate seasonally in orderly formations, following the lead bird in a consistent pattern, representing the couple's observance of propriety and order. Moreover, geese are social birds that maintain hierarchy while living together, expressing the wish that the bride will live harmoniously with her in-laws. Jeonanrye is the ceremony where the groom personally delivers a wooden goose (Mogan, 木雁) or a live goose in a box to the bride's house and performs bows. While modern weddings often include a goose model in the ham (gift box) or omit Jeonanrye entirely, it was an essential procedure in traditional weddings.

query: Why do people visit ancestral graves on Hansik and Cheongmyeong?
knowledge: The custom of visiting graves on Hansik (寒食) and Cheongmyeong (清明) is to tend to ancestors' graves as winter passes and spring arrives. Hansik falls 105 days after the winter solstice, typically around April 5, while Cheongmyeong is one of the 24 solar terms, falling on or very close to Hansik. This period is when the frozen ground thaws and grass begins to grow, making it an appropriate time to maintain graves that became desolate during winter, remove weeds, and repair burial mounds. Traditionally, on Hansik, no fires were lit and cold food was eaten, and people would go to ancestral graves to clear brush and perform simple memorial services. This is called Sijae (時祭) or Hansik Charye. During grave visits, simple offerings such as alcohol, fruits, and vegetables are prepared and placed before the grave, bows are performed, grass is planted, and the burial site is thoroughly cleaned. Hansik grave visits, along with Lunar New Year and Chuseok, constitute one of the three major annual grave visiting periods, an important tradition confirming filial piety and family bonds. Modern practice does not distinguish between Hansik and Cheongmyeong, typically visiting graves in early April.

query: What is the meaning of distributing rice cakes when moving to a new home?
knowledge: The custom of distributing rice cakes when moving is a tradition to establish good relationships with new neighbors and share blessings. On the day of moving or the next day, people made steamed rice cakes with red beans (sirutteok) or white rice cakes (baekseolgi) and distributed them to neighboring houses. Rice cakes symbolize 'sharing and affection,' and the act of distributing them expresses the sentiment 'we are now people of the same village,' representing community consciousness. Particularly, red beans were believed to ward off evil, so red bean rice cakes were commonly used when entering a new house to expel ghosts and evil while inviting blessings. Additionally, neighbors who received rice cakes had the reciprocal custom of returning necessities such as rice, toilet paper, or detergent in the empty containers. This embodied the etiquette of 'not returning empty containers' and the meaning of 'welcoming new neighbors.' While modern practice often involves distributing necessities or cakes instead of rice cakes, or not distributing anything at all, the custom of distributing rice cakes is valued as a beautiful Korean tradition of community culture and sharing affection between neighbors.

query: Why should you not stick a spoon upright in a rice bowl at the table?
knowledge: Sticking a spoon upright in a rice bowl is taboo because this is how offerings are made to the deceased at memorial services. During ancestral rites, there is a procedure called 'Sapsijeongja (揷匙正箸)' where spoons and chopsticks are stuck into the rice (me) for the deceased ancestor to eat. Therefore, if a living person sticks a spoon upright in their rice while eating, it evokes death and is considered very inauspicious and disrespectful. Moreover, sticking a spoon upright in a bowl can be interpreted as cursing someone or wishing them misfortune, making it absolutely unacceptable behavior, especially in front of guests or elders. When temporarily setting down a spoon during a meal, it should be placed neatly on the table next to the bowl or on a spoon rest. This etiquette is still considered basic dining manners in modern society and is an important life etiquette that parents teach children from an early age. It embodies the meaning of distinguishing between the realms of death and life, and not casually using ritual symbolism in daily life.

query: What is the reason for observing three years of mourning (Samnyeongsang) and its meaning?
knowledge: Samnyeongsang (三年喪) is the Confucian mourning system where children wear mourning garments and mourn for three years when their parents pass away. This is based on the teachings in the Confucian classic 'Book of Rites (禮記),' representing repayment for the three years of nurturing received from parents after birth. Confucius explained, 'A person does not leave their parents' embrace until three years old. Three years of mourning is the universal courtesy under heaven.' In practice, 25 months (approximately two years) is typically observed, including from the initial mourning through Sosang (小祥, first anniversary), Daesang (大祥, second anniversary), and Damje (禫祭, two months after Daesang). During the three-year mourning period, chief mourners abstained from meat and alcohol, did not wear colorful clothing, and did not hold weddings or celebrations. This was a way of expressing extreme grief and filial piety, practicing Hyo (孝), the most important virtue in Confucian society. While modern funeral procedures are simplified and full three-year mourning is rare, parents' death is still considered the heaviest mourning, and the spirit continues through memorial services (Gijesa).

query: What is the meaning of Hapgeunrye performed by bride and groom in traditional weddings?
knowledge: Hapgeunrye (合卺禮) is a ceremony in traditional weddings where the bride and groom share ceremonial wine, sealing their bond as husband and wife. 'Hapgeun' means 'joining gourds,' originally using halves of a gourd (bak) as cups. The groom and bride each receive wine in their half-gourd cup, take a sip, exchange cups, and drink again. This symbolizes that the two have now become one body - just as half gourds must join to be complete, the couple joins to form a complete family. Sharing wine means becoming 'people in the same boat,' a promise that the couple will share the same destiny and both joy and sorrow. Hapgeunrye is performed after Gyobaerye and is the final core ceremony of the wedding. Gourds also symbolize fertility due to their many seeds, and wine was considered a sacred beverage for announcing the union of bride and groom and the harmony of two families to the divine. In modern traditional weddings, cups made of wood or brass are used, and this ceremony reenacts the meaning and beauty of traditional weddings.

query: Why is tteokguk (rice cake soup) offered on the morning Charye table during Lunar New Year?
knowledge: Offering tteokguk on the Lunar New Year Charye table symbolizes the beginning of the new year and gaining one year of age. Tteokguk made from sliced white garaetteok (cylinder-shaped rice cake) contains several meanings. First, white symbolizes purity and cleanliness, meaning to start the new year fresh. Second, the round shape of the rice cake slices symbolizes the sun and coins, wishing for abundance and wealth. Third, the long garaetteok represents longevity, and slicing it represents sharing blessings. There's a saying that 'eating one bowl of tteokguk makes you one year older,' and it was believed you gain a year only after eating tteokguk on New Year's Day, making 'how many bowls of tteokguk have you eaten?' an expression for asking someone's age. The meat and egg garnish in tteokguk symbolize Yin-Yang harmony, and the clear, clean broth represents the purity of the new year. When placing tteokguk on the Charye table, it typically replaces me (rice), a way of expressing the holiday's special nature. Tteokguk is the representative food of Lunar New Year, offered to ancestors and shared among family to wish for peace and blessings in the new year - a unique Korean seasonal food.

query: Why is hanbok fastened with the right collar inside when wearing it?
knowledge: When wearing hanbok, fastening it with the right collar inside and left collar outside is called 'Uim (右衽),' a tradition in the East Asian Confucian cultural sphere. 'Uim' means 'the right collar goes inside,' the way living people wear clothing. Conversely, 'Jwaim (左衽),' with the left collar inside, is how burial shrouds are worn on the deceased. Therefore, wearing clothing the opposite way is very inauspicious and evokes death, so it must be avoided. The origin of Uim dates back to ancient China, where Confucius distinguished 'Uim' as a symbol of civilized people and 'Jwaim' as barbarian dress. Korea adopted this Confucian etiquette, making Uim the basic principle of dress from the Three Kingdoms period. Practically, Uim is also a convenient structure for right-handed people to fasten and unfasten clothing. Additionally, it means protecting the heart by having the left breast covered by the inner collar. Not only hanbok but all traditional garments such as durumagi and dopo follow the Uim principle, which is the most fundamental norm of Korean dress culture.

query: What is the reason for writing Jibang during ancestral rites and its meaning?
knowledge: Jibang (紙榜) is a paper memorial tablet representing the spirit of deceased ancestors during memorial services. Originally, rites used wooden spirit tablets called Sinju (神主), but commoners who were not scholar-officials could not make Sinju, and because Sinju production and maintenance were complicated, paper Jibang gradually came into use. Jibang is written with brush on traditional paper just before the service, recording the deceased's title, name, and spirit position, then posted on a screen or wall behind the memorial table. Male ancestors are placed on the left, female ancestors on the right, following the principle of 'Jwajogogubigo (左祖考右妣考).' The format for Jibang is written as '顯考學生府君神位 (Hyeongogohaksaengbugungsinwi),' where '顯 (Hyeon)' is an honorific for the deceased, '考 (Go)' means father, and '妣 (Bi)' means mother. After the service ends, Jibang is burned, meaning the ancestor's spirit is returned to heaven. While modern practice often uses photographs, households following traditional etiquette still write Jibang. Jibang is the core symbol of Confucian ritual, representing sincere devotion to ancestors and proper performance of ceremonies.

query: Why do people wear black clothes and put condolence money in white envelopes when visiting a funeral?
knowledge: Wearing black clothes when visiting a funeral is modern etiquette expressing condolences, while putting condolence money in white envelopes originates from the white mourning garment custom of traditional funeral rites. Traditionally, Korean funeral rites centered on 'white.' Both chief mourners and condolence visitors wore white mourning garments (sobuk, 素服), and white was considered the color of grief, purity, and death. However, in modern times, under Western cultural influence, black has been accepted as the color of mourning, making black suits or formal wear common at funeral homes. Condolence money envelopes still use white, continuing the traditional white mourning garment culture. On the outside of white envelopes, 'Buui (賻儀)' or 'Geunjo (謹弔)' is written, along with the sender's name. Inside, an even amount (not odd) is typically placed, with clean new bills being proper etiquette. When visiting a funeral, avoid colorful clothing or accessories and wear neat, solemn attire. Condolence etiquette expresses courtesy and mourning for the deceased and bereaved family, an important aspect of life ceremonies (Gwanhonsangje) in Korean society.

query: Why should you not hold both spoon and chopsticks at the same time when eating traditional food?
knowledge: Not holding spoon and chopsticks simultaneously is a fundamental principle of Korean traditional dining etiquette. When eating rice or soup with a spoon, chopsticks should be set down on the table, and when picking up side dishes with chopsticks, the spoon should be set down. This etiquette originates from several reasons. First, practically, holding two utensils in one hand makes dining movements uncomfortable and food is easily spilled. Second, eating while gripping both utensils together looks hasty and rude, violating dining etiquette. Third, holding spoon and chopsticks together while eating food was considered greedy and undignified. Fourth, it gives the impression of eating noisily and hastily, behavior especially to be avoided in front of elders. Proper dining etiquette involves eating a spoonful of rice with the spoon, setting the spoon down, picking up a side dish with chopsticks, then picking up the spoon again to eat soup - alternating between utensils. This etiquette emphasizes a calm and leisurely dining attitude, influenced by Confucian courtesy, and is still considered basic dining manners in modern times.

query: What is the meaning of placing white rice cakes and five-colored songpyeon at Baekil and Doljanchi celebrations?
knowledge: Rice cakes at Baekil (100-day) and Doljanchi (first birthday) celebrations contain wishes for the baby's health, longevity, and abundant blessings. Baekil rice cakes mainly use white baekseolgi, where white symbolizes purity and cleanliness, wishing the baby to grow up pure. Baekseolgi is made from glutinous rice, soft and easily digestible, good for the postpartum mother and family caring for the baby. Distributing Baekil rice cakes to neighbors shares the baby's blessings and seeks many people's well-wishes, with recipients reciprocating with thread or rice. At Doljanchi, five-colored songpyeon, red bean rice balls, and injeolmi are prepared. The five colors (red, blue, yellow, white, black) symbolize the Five Elements, wishing the baby to grow harmoniously. Particularly, rainbow-colored five-colored songpyeon embodies wishes for the baby's bright and diverse future. Doljanchi rice cakes are made round, symbolizing completeness and perfection, and the stickiness of glutinous rice represents family harmony and unity. Rice cakes placed on the Dol table are later cut and distributed to guests, Korean traditional sharing culture of dividing joy and blessings.

query: Why is it improper for younger people to leave the table before elders finish eating?
knowledge: Leaving before elders finish their meal is considered a major breach of etiquette. This dining courtesy is based on the Confucian concept of Jangyuyuseo (長幼有序, proper order between elders and juniors), a way of expressing respect and reverence for elders. Traditionally, meals were not merely for satisfying hunger but important social ceremonies where family and community gathered to share affection. Younger people remaining seated while elders eat is a basic attitude of serving and attending to elders. Finishing one's meal and leaving before elders is considered rude behavior, thinking only of oneself without consideration for elders. It also means being available to serve if the elder needs anything. Proper etiquette is to rise together after the elder sets down utensils and finishes eating, when the elder says 'I'm done eating' or 'you may stop eating,' or when they stand up. If one must leave early unavoidably, one should ask permission saying 'I will excuse myself first' or 'thank you for the meal,' bow, and then quietly leave. This dining etiquette continues to be transmitted through family and school education in modern society, representing Korean filial piety culture as exemplary life courtesy.

query: Why does the bride wear a jokduri in Korean traditional weddings?
knowledge: Jokduri is an ornate crown worn on the bride's head in traditional weddings, symbolizing the bride's elevated status and beginning of a new life. Originally, jokduri could only be worn by royalty or wives of high-ranking officials as an authoritative ornament, but during the Joseon Dynasty, ordinary women were permitted to wear jokduri for one day - their wedding day. This is called 'Ilil-wangbi (一日王妃),' meaning being treated like a princess on the wedding day, which happens only once in a lifetime. Jokduri is made of black velvet or silk embellished lavishly with gold and silver leaf, secured with hairpins, tteoljam, and cheopji. Phoenix, peony, and butterfly auspicious patterns are embroidered on top, wishing for wealth, honor, and fertility. Jokduri makes the bride appear taller with raised hair, creating a dignified appearance. Additionally, brides wearing jokduri would cover their faces with a veil (jokdori) or wear rouge and face powder, expressing sacredness and modesty. Jokduri, along with wonsam (圓衫) and hwarot (ceremonial wedding robe), is core to traditional wedding attire, and in modern traditional weddings, the bride must wear it. It represents the most beautiful and precious moment in a Korean woman's life as cultural heritage.

query: Why should fruits not be peeled or cut when placed on ancestral memorial tables?
knowledge: When placing fruits on memorial tables, they must be offered in their complete, whole form, never peeled or cut. This follows the ritual principle of offering sincerity and completeness to ancestors. First, offering whole items is proper etiquette, while peeled or cut items are considered incomplete and disrespectful. Memorial services are ceremonies of utmost sincerity, so fruits are selected to be most complete and unblemished and offered as is. Second, cutting fruits or peeling them is preparation for living people to eat, and since ancestors' spirits receive the 'essence' of food, maintaining the form is important. Third, Confucian etiquette emphasizes 'completeness' and 'purity,' so unprocessed natural forms are considered more pure. Fourth, each fruit follows arrangement rules like Joyulisi (jujube-chestnut-pear-persimmon order) and Hongdongbaekseo, so maintaining the original fruit form is necessary to follow these rules. However, chestnuts are typically peeled down to the inner skin when offered, symbolizing cleanliness. Jujubes are offered whole without removing the pit. Detailed rules exist for fruit stem direction and placement position, demonstrating that memorial services are the most sincere ceremonies honoring ancestors.

query: Why is it improper to receive objects from elders with one hand?
knowledge: When receiving objects from elders, you must always receive with both hands, and receiving with one hand is considered disrespectful behavior. This is based on the Confucian etiquette of Gongsubeop (拱手法), a way of expressing respect and gratitude to elders. Receiving with both hands contains the meaning of 'treasuring,' showing an attitude of valuing both the object received and the grace of the giver. Receiving with one hand is interpreted as treating the object or the other person lightly, an irreverent and presumptuous action. Proper etiquette is to receive the object with the right hand while supporting the right wrist or arm with the left hand, or to receive respectfully with both hands together. While receiving, bow the head slightly and say 'thank you,' lowering your gaze below the other person's face rather than making direct eye contact. Especially when receiving gifts, money, food, or documents from elders, both hands must be used. This is not mere formality but the core of Korean traditional etiquette - physically expressing respect and humility toward others. In modern society, this etiquette is still considered basic manners, and especially in front of elders or guests, it is a behavioral norm that must be observed.

query: What is the meaning of Doljabi at first birthday celebrations and what does each object symbolize?
knowledge: Doljabi is a traditional ceremony at first birthday celebrations where the baby is allowed to grab one of several objects from the Dol table to predict the future. It originated from folk belief that the object the baby first grabs predicts their future occupation, talent, and personality. Traditional Doljabi objects and their meanings are as follows: Thread symbolizes longevity and health, wishing for a long life like thread. Rice or money signifies becoming wealthy and never worrying about food and living. Books or brushes represent becoming a scholar, pursuing academic paths, or excelling in studies. Bow or sword symbolizes military officer or soldier, courage. Ruler means owning much land or becoming a great person. Thread spool means living long and meeting unbreakable connections like thread. Modern additions include stethoscope (doctor), microphone (singer), mouse (computer-related work), ball (athlete), cosmetics (entertainer). Doljabi brings family joy and blesses the baby's future, and while scientifically unfounded, it continues as unique Korean traditional culture. Doljabi is a happy ceremony commemorating the baby's first birthday where the whole family wishes for the baby's bright future.

query: Why is the ham (gift box) sent to the bride's house at night in traditional weddings?
knowledge: In traditional weddings, the custom of sending ham at night originates from Napjing (納徵), the ceremony where 'Hamjinabie' or 'Hamjigi' (ham bearer) delivers wedding gifts from the groom's family to the bride's family. There are several reasons for sending ham at night. First, night is Yin time symbolizing femininity, considered appropriate for delivering gifts to the bride. Second, since weddings are important ceremonies between two families, quietly performing the formality at night rather than making a commotion during the day was considered more respectful. Third, it was consideration to handle the value and contents of gifts as a private matter between two families without revealing them to others. Fourth, there was a custom where villagers would tease the ham bearer and demand ham-gap (payment) along the way, which could be avoided by going at night. The ham contains fabric for the bride's wedding clothes, gold and silver jewelry, and the wedding document (혼서지, specifying the wedding date), wrapped in blue-and-red cloth (청홍보자기) and tied with red string. The ham bearer was typically the groom's friend or village young man who would carry the ham while shouting 'Selling ham!' or 'Ham has arrived!' to announce arrival at the bride's house. The bride's family would receive the ham, set a table to treat the ham bearer, and give him ham-gap (gratuity). While modern practice often involves sending ham during the day, some regions maintain the tradition of nighttime delivery.

query: What is the reason for reading Chukmun (prayer text) during ancestral rites and what does it contain?
knowledge: Chukmun (祝文) is text read to ancestors during memorial services, reporting the purpose of the service, participants, and ritual foods. Chukmun is read after Choheon (first cup offering), called Dokchuk (讀祝). The reason for reading Chukmun is to formally receive the ancestor's spirit and respectfully report who is performing the service and for what purpose. The basic structure of Chukmun is as follows. First, the date and time are stated. Second, the person presiding over the service (filial son, filial daughter-in-law, filial grandson, etc.) is identified. Third, the deceased's title and name are respectfully invoked. Fourth, it states that on the anniversary, we dare to perform this service. Fifth, what food and wine have been prepared is briefly mentioned. Sixth, we humbly perform this service and request Heumhyang (欽享, please partake). Chukmun is written in classical Chinese, and the chief officiant kneels respectfully to read it. While it is read, other participants also prostrate in reverent posture. After reading Chukmun, it is burned over the incense burner, sending it to heaven as smoke - meaning the ancestor's spirit receives the contents of Chukmun. While modern practice may omit or simplify Chukmun, it is an essential procedure in formal Confucian rites, a core ceremony demonstrating sincerity and courtesy toward ancestors.

query: How should one bow and offer words of condolence when visiting a mourning house?
knowledge: When visiting a mourning house for condolences, one must observe solemn etiquette of bowing to the deceased and offering words of comfort to the bereaved family. The condolence procedure is as follows. First, go before the portrait and bow to the deceased. Men typically perform two bows (Jaebae), women perform a flat bow, and one may offer incense or flowers. When bowing, bow slowly and respectfully with a heart of sorrow and mourning. After bowing before the portrait, approach the chief mourner to offer words of comfort. To the chief mourner, do not bow but exchange bows standing, or simply nod lightly. This is to relieve the chief mourner, already burdened in mourning, from the burden of receiving bows. Words of comfort should be simple and sincere expressions. Appropriate phrases include 'I humbly pray for the deceased's peaceful rest,' 'How sorrowful this must be for you,' or 'Please stay strong.' Rather than long statements, brief and earnest comfort is better. Phrases like 'The deceased has gone to a better place' or 'It's fortunate they lived a long life' may not comfort the bereaved but rather make them uncomfortable, so they should be avoided. Also, asking about the cause of death or illness is impolite. The purpose of condolences is to empathize with the family's grief and express mourning, so behave solemnly and quietly, refraining from loud conversation or laughter. After condolences, quietly withdraw without staying long, which is proper etiquette.

query: What is the meaning of cracking bureom (hard nuts) and drinking ear-brightening wine on Daeboreum?
knowledge: On Jeongwol Daeboreum (Great Full Moon, 15th day of the 1st lunar month), cracking bureom and drinking ear-brightening wine is a seasonal custom wishing for health and blessings for the year. Bureom refers to hard-shelled nuts such as chestnuts, walnuts, ginkgo nuts, and pine nuts. Cracking these early on Daeboreum morning while saying 'My boils, you take them' is based on the belief that one will not develop boils (skin diseases) throughout the year and teeth will become strong. The act of cracking hard nuts symbolizes dental health, and the nutrients in nuts actually benefit health, giving practical significance. Ear-brightening wine (Gwibalkisul) is cold rice wine or medicinal wine drunk on Daeboreum morning, with the folk belief that drinking it will brighten the ears, prevent ear diseases, and allow one to hear only good news throughout the year. As the name suggests, it means ears will be sharp throughout the year to hear good news and prevent ear ailments. Drinking cold wine early in the morning also means blocking bad energy for the year and clearing the mind. In addition to this, on Daeboreum people ate five-grain rice, nine types of vegetables, and made fortune wraps (bokssam), enjoying various folk games such as moon house burning, mouse fire play, and ground spirit stepping. Cracking bureom and drinking ear-brightening wine are representative Daeboreum health-wishing customs, beautiful traditions containing ancestors' wisdom and wishes for health.

query: What is the main purpose and background of King Sejong’s creation of Hunminjeongeum?
knowledge: King Sejong the Great created Hunminjeongeum in 1443 (the 25th year of King Sejong’s reign) and promulgated it in 1446. The core purpose of its creation was ‘the spirit of love for the people.’ In the preface to the Hunminjeongeum, there is a famous phrase that says, ‘I will not write Samaddhi by attaching it to the national language,’ and this contains King Sejong’s regret that the people were unable to express their meaning in writing due to the difficulty of Chinese characters. The creation of Hunminjeongeum was accomplished in cooperation with Jiphyeonjeon scholars (Jeong In-ji, Shin Suk-ju, Seong Sam-mun, Choi Hang, etc.), and despite opposition from some of his subjects, including Choi Man-ri, King Sejong pushed through the creation of a written script for the people. This was a practice of Minbon ideology that went beyond the simple spread of letters and aimed at improving the people's literacy and securing cultural independence.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Hunminjeongeum

query: What are the specific circumstances of the Harbin Uprising, in which Ahn Jung-geun shot Ito Hirobumi, and what are the 15 charges he presented?
knowledge: At around 9 a.m. on October 26, 1909, Ahn Jung-geun shot Ito Hirobumi, the first Resident-General of Korea, with a Browning pistol at Harbin Station, killing him on the spot. Immediately after his arrest, Ahn Jung-geun shouted 'Long Live Korean Independence' and presented 15 charges against Ito Hirobumi during the interrogation process. The main crimes are: 1) related to the assassination of Empress Myeongseong, 2) dethronement of Emperor Gojong, 3) forced conclusion of the Japan-Japan Treaty and the Seven Treaties of Settlements with the United States, 4) massacre of innocent Koreans, 5) forcible usurpation of national sovereignty, 6) destruction of peace in the East, 7) suspicion of assassination of Emperor Komei, the father of the Japanese Emperor, 8) deprivation of basic rights of Koreans, 9) blockade of press activities, and 10) forcible imposition of debt on the Korean Empire. Ahn Jung-geun was executed in Lushun Prison on March 26, 1910, and died at the age of 32. He wrote ‘Oriental Peace’ while in prison, emphasizing the need for true peace in East Asia.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Ahn Jung-geun

query: Why did King Jeongjo build Suwon Hwaseong Fortress and what were the innovative construction technologies used in the process?
knowledge: King Jeongjo built Suwon Hwaseong Fortress from 1794 to 1796, and the most important purpose was to move the tomb of his father, Crown Prince Sado (Crown Jangheon), who died trapped in the duju, from Mt. Baebongsan in Yangju to Hwasan in Suwon and commemorate it. King Jeongjo honored Crown Prince Sado as his general and built Yeongwoowon (later Yungneung). In the process of constructing Hwaseong Fortress, innovative construction machines such as heavy machines and type vehicles designed by Silhak scholar Jeong Yak-yong were used. A crane is a crane that uses the principle of a pulley to lift heavy stones, and a crane is a type of cart used to transport heavy materials. Hwaseong is famous for its scientific castle design, and the construction method of using bricks and stones together was applied based on a blueprint called 'Seongseol' for the construction of the castle. The total construction cost was 870,000 nyang, and it is evaluated as a representative example of practical application of Silhak philosophy to architecture.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Hwaseong

query: What was the direct reason for the March 1st Movement and where were the 33 national representatives read the Declaration of Independence?
knowledge: The direct trigger for the March 1st Movement was the sudden death of Emperor Gojong on January 21, 1919, and the doctrine of national self-determination advocated by U.S. President Wilson in 1918. As rumors spread that Gojong's death was caused by Japanese poisoning, national anger heightened, and the principle of national self-determination presented at the Paris Peace Conference after the end of World War I raised hopes for independence. On March 1, 1919, 33 national representatives originally planned to read the Declaration of Independence at Tapgol Park, but changed the venue to Taehwagwan in Jongno for fear of conflict with students. At around 2 p.m., after reading the Declaration of Independence at Taehwagwan, Han Yong-un voluntarily chanted 'Long Live Korean Independence' three times and was arrested by the Japanese police. Meanwhile, students and citizens gathered at Tapgol Park to read the Declaration of Independence and begin a demonstration for national independence, which later spread throughout the country and developed into a huge national movement in which more than 2 million people participated and more than 7,500 people died.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - March 1st Movement

query: When and why was the Tripitaka Koreana produced, and where is it currently stored?
knowledge: The Tripitaka Koreana is a Tripitaka Koreana that was produced over a period of approximately 16 years, from the 23rd year of King Gojong's reign (1236) to the 38th year of his reign (1251). The official name is 'Koryo Tripitaka Koreana (高麗大藏經板)', and it is composed of approximately 81,258 wooden blocks and is called 'Palman Tripitaka Koreana'. The purpose of its production was the Buddhist belief in national defense, in which Goryeo, which moved its capital to Ganghwa Island in 1232 due to the second invasion of Mongolia (Yuan), sought to defeat the Mongolian army with the power of Buddha. It was a re-creation of the previously created Tripitaka Koreana (produced during the Khitan invasion and destroyed by the Mongolian army in 1232), and was a major national project that contained the aspirations of the Goryeo royal family, monks, and people. The Tripitaka Koreana is currently stored in the Janggyeong Panjeon (National Treasure No. 32) of Haeinsa Temple in Hapcheon, Gyeongsangnam-do. The Tripitaka Koreana is a building scientifically designed to control ventilation and humidity, and is listed as a UNESCO World Cultural Heritage. The Tripitaka Koreana itself has been designated as a UNESCO Memory of the World Heritage and its value is recognized.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Tripitaka Koreana

query: What was the strategy that enabled Admiral Yi Sun-sin to win the Battle of Myeongnyang during the Japanese invasions of Korea, and what was the power of the Joseon navy at the time?
knowledge: The Battle of Myeongnyang was a naval battle that took place in Uldolmok, Jindo on September 16, 1597 (lunar calendar). Admiral Yi Sun-sin won a major victory against the Japanese navy of 133 ships (about 300 ships according to Japanese records) with only 12 battleships. After the defeat at the Battle of Chilcheonryang, the rebuilt Joseon navy had only 12 ships (Panokseon) left, but Yi Sun-sin went to war with the determination to die immediately, giving a general warning, 'God still has 12 ships.' The key to the strategy was to use Uldolmok's narrow waterway (approximately 300m) and fast current (11 knots per hour). Yi Sun-sin coordinated the timing of the battle by calculating the time of day when the current was the fastest, and prevented the Japanese fleet from taking advantage of its numerical superiority in the narrow waterway. The Joseon navy, whose morale was boosted by the forward charge of Yi Sun-sin's flagship, destroyed 31 ships with 13 ships and damaged about 90 ships, completely blocking the Japanese navy's advance into the West Sea. The Battle of Myeongnyang is recorded as the most dramatic and winning battle in world naval history.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Battle of Myeongnyang

query: What was the date when Dr. Bong-Gil Yun committed suicide at Hongkou Park in Shanghai and why was that day special?
knowledge: Dr. Yun Bong-gil started an uprising at Hongkou Park in Shanghai, China, on April 29, 1932. This day was Emperor Hirohito's birthday, Cheonjangjeol (天長節), and it was also the day when the Japanese army's victory ceremony for occupying Shanghai was held. Yun Bong-gil was a member of the Korean Patriotic Corps led by Kim Gu, and prepared lunch box bombs and bucket bombs and threw them at Japanese dignitaries attending the ceremony. As a result of the bomb being thrown, Captain Yoshinori Shirakawa, commander of the Japanese forces stationed in Shanghai, died on the spot, Japanese Ambassador to China Mamoru Shigemitsu was seriously injured, losing one leg, and many high-ranking officials, including 3rd Fleet Commander Kichisaburo Nomura, were injured. Yun Bong-gil was arrested at the scene, sentenced to death by a Japanese military court, and died at the age of 25 in Kanazawa Prison on December 19 of that year. With this act, the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea received international attention, and Chiang Kai-shek promised support for the Provisional Government, saying, 'One young Korean man has accomplished what even a million Chinese troops could not do.'
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Yun Bong-gil

query: What are the details of how Joseon surrendered to the Qing Dynasty in the Manchu War and the humiliation that King Injo suffered in Samjeondo?
knowledge: The Manchu War was a war in which Taizong of the Qing invaded Joseon from December 1636 to January 1637. The outbreak broke out when the Qing changed the name of the country from Later Jin to Qing and requested Joseon to have a military-subject relationship, but King Injo refused. When 120,000 Qing troops invaded in December 1636, King Injo tried to take refuge in Ganghwa Island, but the road was blocked and he had to take refuge in Namhansanseong Fortress. Joseon, which was isolated in Namhansanseong Fortress for 47 days, could no longer endure due to lack of food and the harsh winter cold, and on January 30, 1637, King Injo decided to surrender to the Qing. King Injo went to the Suhangdan (受降壇) prepared in Samjeondo (currently Songpa-gu, Seoul) and performed the Sambaegugodurye (三拜九叩頭禮) ritual of bowing three times and bowing nine times in front of King Taejong of the Qing Dynasty. This was the greatest humiliation for the king of Joseon. The Qing erected the Samjeondo Monument (Monument to the Great Qing Emperor's Merit) to record Joseon's surrender, took Crown Prince Sohyeon and Prince Bongrim (later King Hyojong) and other princes and subjects hostage, and took about 500,000 Koreans as prisoners.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Manchu War

query: What were the strategic factors that led to the success of the Incheon Landing Operation during the Korean War, and who was in command of this operation?
knowledge: The Inchon Landing Operation was a landing operation commanded by UN Forces Commander Marshal Douglas MacArthur on September 15, 1950, and was a decisive operation that turned the tide of the Korean War. The name of the operation was ‘Operation Chromite’, and approximately 75,000 troops were deployed. A key strategic factor for success was taking advantage of Incheon's extreme tidal range (approximately 9-10m). Most military experts judged that landing was impossible due to the large tidal range, wide tidal flats, and Wolmido fortress, but MacArthur predicted that the North Korean army would neglect defense for that very reason. The operation was carried out exactly at the time of high tide, and after occupying Wolmido first in the early morning of September 15, they successfully landed in Incheon at 5:30 pm. Through this operation, the UN forces, who had been pushed back to the Nakdong River defense line, turned the tide and recaptured Seoul on September 28, and in October broke through the 38th parallel and advanced north. The Incheon Landing Operation is evaluated as the highlight of the 20th century's amphibious operations.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Incheon Landing Operation
Ministry of Defense Military Compilation Research Institute

query: What is the background to why martyr Yu Gwan-sun led the Aunae Market independence movement and what was the sentence she received?
knowledge: Yu Gwan-sun was born in Cheonan, South Chungcheong Province in 1902, and participated in the March 1st Movement in 1919 while attending Ewha Hakdang General Department. After the March 1st Movement, when Japan ordered schools across the country to close, Yu Gwan-sun went back to her hometown of Cheonan and led the independence movement at Aunae Marketplace in Byeongcheon-myeon, Cheonan, on April 1, 1919 (March 1 in the lunar calendar). It was the day when the Byeongcheon 5-day market was held at Aunae Market, and about 3,000 people waved the Taegeukgi and shouted ‘Long Live Korean Independence’. As Japanese military police and soldiers launched a violent crackdown, 19 people, including Yu Gwan-sun's father Yu Jung-kwon and mother Lee So-je, died at the scene and about 30 were injured. Yu Gwan-sun was arrested and sentenced to five years in prison by the Gongju District Court, but the sentence was reduced to three years in prison on appeal. Yu Gwan-sun, who was imprisoned in Seodaemun Prison, was tortured while leading the independence movement while in prison, and died at the age of 18 on September 28, 1920 (August 20th of the lunar calendar). The government of the Republic of Korea posthumously awarded him the Independence Medal of the Order of Merit for National Foundation in 1962, and in 2019, he was upgraded to the title of Order of the Republic of Korea.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Yu Gwan-sun

query: What was the main role that Mr. Kim Gu played in the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea and the purpose of organizing the Korean Patriotic Corps?
knowledge: Baekbeom Kim Gu (1876-1949) was a key leader of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea. He was appointed as the first Director of the Police Bureau immediately after the establishment of the Provisional Government in Shanghai in 1919. After serving as Minister of State in 1926, he served as President of the Provisional Government from March 1940 to 1947. Kim Gu's greatest achievement was organizing the Korean Patriotic Corps in 1931. The Korean Patriotic Association was a secret organization to wage an armed struggle against the Japanese invasion, and took an oath to 'swear to slaughter the leaders of the enemy nation in order to restore the independence and freedom of the fatherland.' Representative activities of the Korean Patriotic Group include the assassination of Dr. Lee Bong-chang on January 8, 1932, when he threw a bomb at the Japanese Emperor in Tokyo, and the assassination of Dr. Yun Bong-gil at Hongkou Park in Shanghai on April 29, 1932. In particular, after the Yun Bong-gil Incident, Chiang Kai-shek of the Chinese Nationalist government promised support for the Provisional Government, which became the basis for the Provisional Government to move to Chongqing and continue its activities. Kim Gu founded the Korean Liberation Army in 1940 and achieved liberation in 1945, but was assassinated by Ahn Du-hee at Gyeonggyojang on June 26, 1949.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Kim Gu

query: What are the core contents of the Joseon Revolutionary Declaration written by Shin Chae-ho in 1923 and the independence movement methodology he advocated?
knowledge: Danjae Shin Chae-ho (1880-1936) was asked to write the Declaration of the Uiyeoldan by Kim Won-bong, the leader of the Uiyeoldan, in December 1922, and completed the Joseon Revolutionary Declaration in January 1923. This declaration consists of approximately 6,400 characters and is a revolutionary independence movement platform that criticizes the existing diplomatic and preparedness theories and emphasizes the people's direct revolution. The core content is 'the theory of direct revolution of the people', which begins with the famous phrase, 'The first step in our revolution is destruction.' Shin Chae-ho argued that the economic exploitation agencies, political pressure agencies, and social bondage agencies of Japanese imperialism should be destroyed, and the evil Korean wealthy people and pro-Japanese supporters who defended them should also be eliminated. In addition, he emphasized independence through armed struggle and popular uprising, advocating 'defending the right to survival of the Joseon people'. The Joseon Revolutionary Declaration mixed nationalist and anarchist ideologies, and Shin Chae-ho later became absorbed in the anarchist movement. Shin Chae-ho was arrested by Japanese police in Taiwan in 1928 and sentenced to 10 years in Lushun Prison, where he died on February 21, 1936 while serving his sentence.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean National Culture - Joseon Revolutionary Declaration

query: What was the process of poet Yoon Dong-ju preparing his poetry collection ‘Sky, Wind, Stars, and Poetry’ during his time at Yonhee College, and what was his final outcome?
knowledge: Yun Dong-ju (1917-1945) was born in Bukgando, Manchuria, and graduated from the Department of Liberal Arts at Yonhui College in 1941. To commemorate his graduation, he selected 19 poems he had written and made 3 copies in his own handwriting, of which 1 copy was given to his junior Byeong-wook Jeong, 1 copy was given to Professor Yang-ha Lee, and 1 copy was kept for himself. It was originally planned to be published in a limited edition of 77 copies, but it was put on hold as Professor Lee Yang-ha discouraged publication for fear of passing the Japanese censorship. In 1942, Yun Dong-ju entered the English Department of Rikkyo University in Tokyo, Japan, and then transferred to the English Department of Doshisha University in Kyoto in the fall of the same year. Just before returning home in July 1943, he and Song Mong-gyu were arrested by the Japanese police on charges of anti-Japanese ideology and sentenced to two years in prison. While serving his sentence at Fukuoka Prison, he received an injection believed to be a biological experiment and died in prison on February 16, 1945 at the age of 28. His death occurred only six months before liberation. Yun Dong-ju's poetry collection 'Sky, Wind, Stars and Poetry' was first published by Jeongeumsa on January 30, 1948 through the arrangement of Jeong Byeong-wook after liberation, and included 31 poems. His representative works include ‘Foreword’, ‘The Night of Counting Stars’, and ‘The Cross’.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Yun Dong-ju
Yonsei University Yun Dong-ju Memorial Hall

query: What were the purposes and activities of Daesung School and Heungsadan, founded by Dosan Ahn Chang-ho?
knowledge: Dosan Ahn Chang-ho (1878-1938) based his independence movement on skill development and national reform through education. In 1908, Daesung School (大成學校) was established in Pyongyang, with Yun Chi-ho as the principal and Ahn Chang-ho himself as the vice principal. Daeseong School was a national educational institution that taught new science and patriotic ideology, and also served as an educational institution for the secret society Shinminhoe. After producing 19 students for the first class in the spring of 1912, the school was forced to close by the Japanese. In May 1913, Heungsadan was founded in San Francisco, USA. Heungsadan was an organization that aimed to foster the strength of the nation with the four main principles of 'resilience, resistance, loyalty, and bravery.' It was organized by 25 promoters representing the eight provinces of Joseon, and carried out a movement to cultivate talent and transform the nation. Ahn Chang-ho went into exile in Shanghai in 1919 and participated in the establishment of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea, serving as Minister of the Interior and Minister of State. After the Yun Bong-gil Incident in 1932, he was arrested and tortured by the Japanese police, and died at the age of 60 at Kyungsung University Hospital on March 10, 1938.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Ahn Chang-ho

query: What were the main figures who caused the Gapsin Coup in 1884 and the 14 reform platforms presented by the Gaehwa Party?
knowledge: The Gapsin Coup was a political reform movement initiated by radical enlightenment faction members such as Kim Ok-gyun, Park Young-hyo, Seo Jae-pil, Seo Gwang-beom, and Hong Young-sik on December 4, 1884 (October 17 in the lunar calendar). Taking advantage of the withdrawal of some of the Qing army due to the Sino-French War, he staged a coup d'état at the inauguration ceremony of the Ujungguk State, eliminated the Min clan's kin forces, and established an enlightened regime. The main contents of the 14-point reform platform announced on December 6 are: 1) Elimination of the relationship between nobles with the Qing, 2) Abolition of clan clans and establishment of equal rights for the people, 3) Simplification through reform of the Jijo Law, 4) Abolition of the Eunuch Department, 5) Punishment of Tamgwan-ori, 6) Abolition of Gyujanggak, and 7) Establishment of a constable system. This was a modern reform platform that influenced the Gabo Reform and the reform plan of the Independence Association. However, with the intervention of 1,500 Qing soldiers, the coup failed in three days, Hong Young-sik and Park Young-gyo were assassinated, and Kim Ok-gyun, Park Young-hyo, and Seo Jae-pil fled to Japan. Kim Ok-gyun was assassinated by assassin Hong Jong-woo in Shanghai in 1894. Although the Gapsin Coup failed, it played a pioneering role in modern Korean political reform.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Gapsin Coup

query: What was the background of the Donghak Peasant Movement centered on Jeon Bong-jun in 1894 and the progress of the Gobu Uprising and the Battle of Hwangtohyeon?
knowledge: The Donghak Peasant Movement (Donghak Peasant Revolution) was a large-scale peasant uprising centered on Jeolla-do in 1894 (Gapoh year), which was a resistance to the disturbances of the Samjeong (Jeonjeong, Gunjeong, and Hwangok) in the late Joseon Dynasty and the exploitation of Tamgwanori. It began on February 15, 1894 (lunar calendar) when Gobu farmers, led by Jeon Bong-jun, protested against the tyranny of Gobu governor Jo Byeong-gap, destroying Manseokbo and attacking Gobu government offices. This was the Gobu Uprising, and it later spread throughout the country. On April 7, 1894 (lunar calendar, May 11 on the solar calendar), about 4,000 peasant troops led by Jeon Bong-jun fought their first large-scale battle in Hwangtohyeon (currently Deokcheon-myeon, Jeongeup-si, Jeollabuk-do) against 800 government troops led by Jeolla governor Kim Mun-hyeon. The peasant army was armed with bamboo spears and matchlocks, but won a great victory by throwing the government army into confusion with a surprise attack at dawn. Afterwards, the peasant army occupied Jeonju Castle (April 27), and the government signed the Jeonju Agreement with the peasant army and accepted the 12 articles of the government reform plan. However, as the Japanese army dispatched troops to Joseon, the peasant army recovered in September, and was defeated and suppressed in the Battle of Ugeumchi, Gongju. Jeon Bong-jun was arrested and executed in March 1895.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Donghak Peasant Movement

query: What were the major battles and scale of territorial expansion that King Gwanggaeto conquered during his reign?
knowledge: King Gwanggaeto (reigned 391-412) was the 19th king of Goguryeo. During his 21-year reign, he conquered 64 provinces and 1,400 villages and developed Goguryeo into a great empire. The main conquest activities were as follows: In July 392, Baekje attacked and captured about 10 castles, including Seokhyeonseong Fortress, and in 396, it occupied 58 castles and 700 villages and took control of the area north of the Han River. In 395, he defeated 600-700 600-700 villages of the three Khitan factions, and in 398, he conquered Shuxin and stabilized the northeastern border. In 400, in response to Silla's request for relief, a 50,000-strong army was dispatched and the Japanese army was defeated. In the war with Later Yan, they captured Shugun Castle in 402, Liaodong Province in 405, and Mujeo Province in 406, and in 407, they mobilized 50,000 men and occupied six provinces. In 410, he personally led an army and conquered Eastern Buyeo. King Gwanggaeto's achievements are recorded in detail in the tombstone of King Gwanggaeto the Great (built in 414, height 6.39m) located in Ji'an, Jilin Province, China, and the 1,775-character epitaph is a key material for research on Goguryeo history. His territory extended to the Songhua River to the north, the Han River to the south, Liaodong to the west, and the East Coast to the east.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Culture - Gwanggaeto the Great

query: What are the major cultural assets built by Queen Seondeok, the first queen of Silla, during her reign and what are their significance?
knowledge: Queen Seondeok (reigned 632-647) was the 27th king of Silla and the first queen in Korean history. She was born as the eldest daughter of King Jinpyeong, and when King Jinpyeong, who had no sons, died, she ascended to the throne through the decision of the Hwabaekhoe. During his reign, three major cultural assets were built. First, Bunhwangsa Temple (芬皇寺) was founded in 634, which is where the Bunhwangsa Temple Stone Pagoda (National Treasure), the first brick pagoda of Silla, is located. Second, Cheomseongdae (瞻星臺) was built in 637. Cheomseongdae is the oldest existing astronomical observatory in East Asia. It is a stone structure with a height of 9.17m and was used for astronomical observations necessary for farming. Third, the nine-story wooden pagoda of Hwangnyongsa Temple was built in 645. This wooden pagoda, built at the suggestion of Master Jajang, is about 80 meters high, and each floor symbolizes the nine enemy countries of Silla (Wae, Junghwa, Owol, Takla, Eungyu, Malgal, Danguk, Yeojeok, and Yemaek), and contains the will to protect the country by defeating them. Queen Seondeok also appointed Kim Chun-chu and Kim Yu-sin to lay the foundation for the unification of the three kingdoms, and dispatched foreign students to the Tang Dynasty to accept advanced civilization.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Queen Seondeok

query: What was General Kim Yu-shin's strategy of defeating Gyebaek's deadly force in the Battle of Hwangsanbeol in 660 and what was Hwarang's role?
knowledge: The Battle of Hwangsanbeol was a battle between Silla and Baekje that took place on July 9-10, 660 (lunar calendar, August 20-21 solar calendar) at Hwangsanbeol, Yeonsan-myeon, Nonsan, Chungcheongnam-do. When Silla's Kim Yu-sin led 50,000 troops and advanced toward Baekje's capital Sabiseong, Baekje's General Gyebaek led a 5,000-strong force to fight him at Hwangsanbeol. Before competing, Gyebaek killed his family and fought to the death. The Baekje army won all of the first four engagements, and the Silla army's morale fell. At this time, 16-year-old Hwarang Gwanchang (官昌) under Kim Pum-il, the son of Kim Yu-sin, made a short charge into the enemy camp at the urging of his father, but was captured. Gyebaek was moved by Gwanchang's bravery and released him, but Gwanchang charged again and was killed. Subsequently, another Hwarang, Bangul, also entered the enemy camp and was killed. The Silla army, whose morale was boosted by the sacrifice of the Hwarangs, launched an all-out offensive and defeated the Baekje death squad, and General Gyebaek was also killed. With this victory, the Silla-Tang allied forces captured Sabiseong Fortress on July 18 and destroyed Baekje. The Battle of Hwangsanbeol is recorded as a representative example of the sacrifice and loyalty of the Hwarang spirit.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - Battle of Hwangsanbeol
Ministry of Defense Military Compilation Research Institute

query: What was the background to the April 19 Revolution in 1960 and the events leading up to President Syngman Rhee's resignation?
knowledge: The April 19 Revolution was a democratization movement initiated by students and citizens in protest against the dictatorship of the Syngman Rhee government and the March 15 election fraud in 1960. In the 4th presidential and vice-presidential elections on March 15, 1960, the Liberal Party government committed large-scale election fraud. Methods such as three-member groups, 40% advance voting, open voting, and ballot box swapping were used. A protest against election fraud occurred in Masan on March 15, and nationwide anger exploded on April 11 when the body of student Kim Ju-yeol, who had participated in the protest, was found with tear gas in his eyes in the waters off Masan. On April 18, an incident occurred where Korea University students were attacked by political thugs while returning home after a protest. On April 19, approximately 100,000 college and high school students and citizens nationwide protested in Seoul, and 186 people died as a result of police shooting. On April 25, university professors participated in a protest with the slogan, 'Repay the students' blood.' On April 26, when the National Assembly unanimously passed a resolution demanding the immediate resignation of Syngman Rhee, Syngman Rhee issued a statement saying, "I will resign from the presidency if the people wish." On May 29th, he went into exile in Hawaii.
sources: Encyclopedia of Korean Folk Culture - April 19 Revolution

query: What is the background to the May 18 Gwangju Democratization Movement in 1980 and how the new military regime of Chun Doo-hwan expanded martial law?
knowledge: The 5.18 Gwangju Democratization Movement was a democratization movement carried out from May 18 to 27, 1980 by the citizens of Gwangju and South Jeolla Province, demanding the resignation of Chun Doo-hwan and other new military forces and the abolition of martial law. After Park Chung-hee's death in the October 26 incident in 1979, the new military government centered on Security Command Commander Chun Doo-hwan seized military power through the December 12 military revolt. On April 14, 1980, Chun Doo-hwan was appointed as Director of the Central Intelligence Agency and took control of the intelligence agency.
